data.title: Andy Roddick
data.meta_description: News about Andy Roddick, including commentary and archival articles published in The New York Times.
data.text:
Ben Shelton Advances to U.S. Open Semifinal Against Novak Djokovic

Shelton, 20, becomes the youngest American man to reach a U.S. Open semifinal since Andy Roddick in 2003.

By Matthew Futterman

When Coco Gauff and Zendaya Need Tennis Tips, They Ask Brad Gilbert

Gilbert, a former pro, coached Andre Agassi to a U.S. Open victory in 1994. Now he’s advising Gauff — in between calling matches — at this year’s tournament.

By Matthew Futterman

The Big Three Are Now Just Two. Who Will Lead Tennis’s Next Generation?

Roger Federer’s retirement will augur opportunities for a new generation of players not named Rafael Nadal or Novak Djokovic.

By David Waldstein

On Tennis

Sustained Excellence, Not Titles, Puts Andy Roddick in Hall of Fame

Roddick won only one major, but also a Davis Cup and a No. 1 ranking, and for a decade, he was present among the game’s elite. He and Kim Clijsters will be inducted in July.

By Christopher Clarey

Before Saying Farewell at U.S. Open, Mardy Fish Intends to Stay for a While

Fish, whose late-career surge was derailed by an anxiety disorder three years ago, is playing well as he heads into his final tournament.

By Douglas Robson

Q&A

Andy Roddick Talks About His Life After Tennis

Roddick, 32, who retired from tennis in 2012, spoke about living with the knowledge that he “could still be out there” and his coming assignment with the BBC at Wimbledon.

Interview by Christopher Clarey

Roddick’s Doubles Comeback Is Dashed

Andy Roddick hoped to come out of retirement to enter the United States Open with Mardy Fish, but Roddick was denied because he was not drug tested three months before the event.

By Ben Rothenberg

Frank Bruni

A Clever Solution to an Olympic Problem

LGBT advocates think they’ve found a safe way for athletes to stand against Russia’s anti-gay laws.

By Frank Bruni

Finding Lessons in Stumbles, American Aims for the Top Again

Ryan Harrison, once hailed as the next American tennis idol, has stumbled over the past year. But with a new coach and a new attitude, he hopes to rise again.

By Ben Rothenberg

Straight Sets

Absence of American Men in Top 20 Is Met With a Shrug

Players at this week’s Western & Southern Open more than anything said that they were not personally worried about the men’s exodus from top 20 for the first time since the rankings began in 1973.

By Ben Rothenberg
